conclusion: The elevator starts from rest at t = 0, so the initial velocity v0 = 0.
From t = 0 to t = 1 s, the acceleration increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s².
From t = 1 to t = 4 s, the acceleration is constant at 2 m/s².
From t = 4 to t = 5 s, the acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0.
From t = 5 to t = 55 s, the acceleration is 0 (constant velocity).
From t = 55 to t = 56 s, the acceleration increases linearly from 0 to -2 m/s².
From t = 56 to t = 59 s, the acceleration is constant at -2 m/s².
From t = 59 to t = 60 s, the acceleration decreases linearly from -2 m/s² to 0.

premise: Average acceleration a = 1 m/s² from t = 0 to t = 1 s.
conclusion: Velocity increase: v = a × t = 1 × 1 = 1 m/s.

premise: Acceleration a = 2 m/s² from t = 1 to t = 4 s.
conclusion: Velocity increase: v = a × t = 2 × 3 = 6 m/s. Total velocity at t = 4: 1 + 6 = 7 m/s.

premise: Average acceleration a = 1 m/s² from t = 4 to t = 5 s.
conclusion: Velocity decrease: v = a × t = 1 × 1 = 1 m/s. Total velocity at t = 5: 7 - 1 = 6 m/s.

premise: Constant velocity from t = 5 to t = 55 s.
Average acceleration a = -1 m/s² from t = 55 to t = 56 s.
conclusion: Velocity decrease: v = a × t = -1 × 1 = -1 m/s. Total velocity at t = 56: 6 - 1 = 5 m/s.

premise: Acceleration a = -2 m/s² from t = 56 to t = 59 s.
conclusion: Velocity decrease: v = a × t = -2 × 3 = -6 m/s. Total velocity at t = 59: 5 - 6 = -1 m/s.
